Pcidss.DisplayName: Ensure that all system components and software are protected from known vulnerabilities by installing applicable vendor-supplied security patches

CveDescriptions.Description: Webpack is a module bundler. Its main purpose is to bundle JavaScript files for usage in a browser, yet it is also capable of transforming, bundling, or packaging just about any resource or asset. The webpack developers have discovered a DOM Clobbering vulnerability in Webpackâ€™s `AutoPublicPathRuntimeModule`. The DOM Clobbering gadget in the module can lead to cross-site scripting (XSS) in web pages where scriptless attacker-controlled HTML elements (e.g., an `img` tag with an unsanitized `name` attribute) are present. Real-world exploitation of this gadget has been observed in the Canvas LMS which allows a XSS attack to happen through a javascript code compiled by Webpack (the vulnerable part is from Webpack). DOM Clobbering is a type of code-reuse attack where the attacker first embeds a piece of non-script, seemingly benign HTML markups in the webpage (e.g. through a post or comment) and leverages the gadgets (pieces of js code) living in the existing javascript code to transform it into executable code. This vulnerability can lead to cross-site scripting (XSS) on websites that include Webpack-generated files and allow users to inject certain scriptless HTML tags with improperly sanitized name or id attributes. This issue has been addressed in release version 5.94.0. All users are advised to upgrade. There are no known workarounds for this issue.

GlossaryItems.Value: Parameter error_page sets user-defined error pages. If it is not set some valuable infromation such as stack traces could be shown to users through error pages.

An application does not sufficiently validate user input that allows an attacker to create a malformed log file or inject an arbitrary code.

A web application can generate log file entities based on user input data. Because of insufficient data processing, an attacker can inject dividing characters and therefore create a malformed log file entity, making it impossible to automatically process this file. Also, an attacker can inject malware and use it for further attacks.

Please fins the vulnerable script example below:

    $result = $authService->authenticate($login, $password);

    if (!$result->isValid()) {
        $log->write("Authentication failed for user '$login'");
    }

Recommendations

We recommend you process log file data to delete or escape formaztting characters.

Links

  • Log Forging

  • CWE-117: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs

Enables or disables emitting nginx version in error messages and in the â€œServerâ€ response header field. Attacker could use known vulnerabilities in current web-server's version. Recommended to deactivate.
Enable HTTPS protocol for current virtual server.
Specifies file with PEM-certificate for current virtual server.
Specifies file with PEM secret key for current virtual server.
Specifies allowed ciphers. Ciphers are specified in a format supported by the OpenSSL library.

If ssl_prefer_server_ciphers directive value is Off, in certain conditions an attacker can conduct BEAST attack (Browser Exploit Against SSL/TLS). If an attacker can listen user traffic MITM) via SSL (if earlier TLS versions are used) and impact the traffic in user's browser considering Same Origin Policy (for example via XSS or HTML Injection attack), this makes it possible to compromise user credentials send via this protocol.â€‹
Specifies size and type of caches that store session parameters.
Allow or deny attachment of OCSP-responses by the server.

The software contains a hard-coded password, which it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components. A hard-coded password typically leads to a significant authentication failure that can be difficult for the system administrator to detect. Once detected, it can be difficult to fix, so the administrator may be forced into disabling the product entirely. There are two main variations: Inbound: the software contains an authentication mechanism that checks for a hard-coded password. Outbound: the software connects to another system or component, and it contains hard-coded password for connecting to that component. In the Inbound variant, a default administration account is created, and a simple password is hard-coded into the product and associated with that account. This hard-coded password is the same for each installation of the product, and it usually cannot be changed or disabled by system administrators without manually modifying the program, or otherwise patching the software. If the password is ever discovered or published (a common occurrence on the Internet), then anybody with knowledge of this password can access the product. Finally, since all installations of the software will have the same password, even across different organizations, this enables massive attacks such as worms to take place. The Outbound variant applies to front-end systems that authenticate with a back-end service. The back-end service may require a fixed password which can be easily discovered. The programmer may simply hard-code those back-end credentials into the front-end software. Any user of that program may be able to extract the password. Client-side systems with hard-coded passwords pose even more of a threat, since the extraction of a password from a binary is usually very simple.
